Symptoms:
Dark, irregularly-shaped lesions develop on the foliage, blossoms and developing fruits
The fungal disease forms pale yellow or olive-green spots on the upper surface of leaves and fruits. 
Dark, velvety spots may appear on the lower surface of the leaf.
Consequences:
Rarely kills its host.
Scabby spots are sunken and tan and may have velvety spores in the center. 
As these spots mature, they become larger and turn brown and corky. 
Infected fruits and leaves become distorted and may crack allowing entry of secondary organisms. 
Severely affected fruits and leaves may drop, especially when young.
Severity of Diease: Rarely kills a plant. If severity level is high in some case, it makes the plant prone to other infections.
Natural Remedies:
With or without chemicals, there is no viable cure for an infected tree during the season once damage is present.
Spray the apple tree foliage with a fertilizer mixture containing 5% urea.
Can also churn the fallen leaves so that the fungus cannot grow in the suitable weather.
Insectisides/Pesticides:
Benzimidazole fungicides
Organocide Plant Doctor
Bonide Orchard Spray
Precautions:
Choose resistant varieties when possible.
Rake under trees and destroy infected leaves to reduce the number of fungal spores available to start the disease cycle over again next spring.
Water in the evening or early morning hours (avoid overhead irrigation) to give the leaves time to dry out before infection can occur.
Spread a 3- to 6-inch layer of compost under trees, keeping it away from the trunk, to cover soil and prevent splash dispersal of the fungal spores.
For best control, spray liquid copper soap early, two weeks before symptoms normally appear. Alternatively, begin applications when disease first appears, and repeat at 7 to 10 day intervals up to blossom drop.

Reason:
Fungal
Infects fruits, leaves and bark.
Symptoms: Often limited to leaf symptoms such as purple spots on upper leaf surfaces
Consequences:
As these spots age, the margins remain purple, but the centers dry out and turn yellow to brown. 
Over time, the spots expand and heavily infected leaves drop from the tree. 
Infected branches or limbs will show characteristic red-brown sunken areas that expand each year.
Severity of Diease:
Fruit infection is the most destructive form of this pathogen and begins with infected flowers, before fruits expand.
When fruits are tiny and green, you’ll notice red flecks or purplish pimples that enlarge as the fruit does. 
Mature fruit lesions take on a bulls-eye appearance, with bands of brown and black areas expanding outward from a central point in each lesion. 
Commonly, black rot disease causes blossom end rot or mummification of the fruits on the tree.
Natural Remedies:
Treating black rot on apple trees starts with sanitation because fungal spores overwinter on fallen leaves, mummified fruits, dead bark and cankers, it’s important to keep all the fallen debris and dead fruit cleaned up and away from the tree.
During the winter, check for red cankers and remove them by cutting them out or pruning away the affected limbs at least six inches beyond the wound. 
Destroy all infected tissue immediately and keep a watchful eye out for new signs of infection.
Insectisides/Pesticides: general purpose fungicides, like copper-based sprays and lime sulfur, can be used to control black rot, nothing will improve apple black rot like removing all sources of spores.
Precautions: make sure to remove any injured or insect-invaded fruits to avoid re-infection

Symptoms:
On Juniper - Reddish brown gall on young twigs
On Apple and Crab Apples - pale yellow pinhead sized spots on the upper surface of the leaves shortly after bloom. theydevelop into orange spots that are noticeable. The Orange spots might develop on Fruits as well.
Consequences: Heavily infected leaves may drop prematurely.
Natural Remedies: Remove cedars located in one mile radius of Apple trees.
Insectisides/Pesticides: Fungicides can be sprayed four times at an interval of 7 to 10 days.
Precautions:
Choose resistant cultivars when available.
Rake up and dispose of fallen leaves and other debris from under trees.

Reason:
Fungal
Typically, it takes 1/10th of an inch of rain or irrigation and temperatures of 50°F or more for spring primary infections to occur
Symptoms: Light roughly-circular, powdery looking patches on young, susceptible leaves (newly unfolded, and light green expanding leaves). Older leaves develop an age-related (ontogenic) resistance to powdery mildew and are naturally more resistant to infection than younger leaves.
Consequences:
As the season progresses and infection is spread by wind, leaves may become distorted, curling upward.
Severe infections may cause leaves to pucker and twist. 
Newly developed leaves on new shoots become progressively smaller, are often pale and may be distorted.
Natural Remedies:
Manage irrigation.
Select resistant varieties
Prune out and destroy severely infected shoots as they appear. It is important to remove the early-spring
infected shoots.
Milk sprays, made with 40% milk and 60% water, are an effective home remedy for use on a wide range of plants. For best results, spray plant leaves as a preventative measure every 10-14 days.
Insectisides/Pesticides:
For chemical management see the WSU Crop Protection Guide for the appropriate control program.
Powdery mildew and scab are usually treated with the same fungicide and timing.
Precautions: Plant resistant cultivars in sunny locations whenever possible.

Reason:
Foliar Fungal disease
Poor airflow, low sunlight, overcrowding, improper soil nutrient and irrigation management, and poor soil drainage can all contribute to the propagation of the disease.
Symptoms:
Leaf lesions, discoloration (chlorosis), and foliar blight.
Distinct symptoms are rectangular, brown to gray necrotic lesions that run parallel to the leaf, spanning the spaces between the secondary leaf veins
Severity of Diease: Severity depends on the weather conditions
Insectisides/Pesticides: Management techniques include crop resistance, crop rotation, residue management, use of fungicides, and weed control.

Symptoms:
Often appear after silking.
Small, round to elongate brown pustules form on both leaf surfaces and other above ground parts of the plant.

As the pustules mature they become brown to black.
Consequences:
As the pustules mature they become brown to black.

If disease is severe, the leaves may yellow and die early.
Severity of Diease: If disease is severe, the leaves may yellow and die early.
Natural Remedies:
Use of resistant hybrids.
Timely planting of corn early during the growing season may help to avoid high inoculum levels or environmental conditions that would promote disease development.

Symptoms:
Cigar-shaped or elliptical necrotic gray-green lesions on the leaves that range from one to seven inches long.
These lesions may first appear as narrow, tan streaks that run parallel to the leaf veins.
Consequences: diseased corn plants are more susceptible to stalk rot than are healthy plants
Duration: One complete cycle on susceptible plants takes approximately 10 to 14 days, whereas it takes about 20 days on plants with resistance.
Severity of Diease:
Relatively localized.
In conditions with high humidity, the fungus will produce new spores at the leaf surface, which are spread by rain or wind through the crop and create cycles of secondary infection.
Precautions: Ways to change cropping practices to control the disease include reducing the amount of infected residue left in a field, managing weeds to improve airflow and reduce humidity, and encouraging residue decomposition with tillage.

Reason: Bacterium, Disease emergence favored by warm, wet conditions; the pathogen can be enter a field on seed and transplants and can be spread within a field by wind-driven rain, clipping plants and aerosols.
Symptoms: Water-soaked lesions that dry out and turn brown forming on the underside of the leaves; raised brown cankers on stems; cracked brown lesions on fruit.
Severity of Diease: Very serious as can cause total crop loss.
Insectisides/Pesticides: Chemical elements labeled for this purpose: Copper-based compounds, Mancozeb + Copper Hydroxide, Streptomycin Sulfate, Bacteriophage, Acibenzolar-S-Methyl.
Precautions: Use disease free planting material; remove and destroy all crop debris after harvest, or plow material deeply under soil.

Reason: Fungal, Lower leaves become infected when in contact with contaminated soil, either through direct contact or through rain-splashed soil.
Symptoms:
Initially, small dark spots form on older foliage near the ground.
Leaf spots are round, brown and can grow up to half inch in diameter.
Larger spots have target-like concentric rings. ...
Severely infected leaves turn brown and fall off, or dead, dried leaves may cling to the stem.
Severity of Diease: Very serious as can cause total crop loss.
Insectisides/Pesticides: Use of fungicides like Penthiopyrad, Boscalid, Pyraclostrobin, Fenamidone, Azoxystrobrin, Mancozeb
Precautions: Use pathogen-free seed, or collect seed only from disease-free plants, Rotate out of tomatoes and related crops for at least two years., Avoid working in plants when they are wet from rain, irrigation, or dew., Fertilize properly to maintain vigorous plant growth. Particularly, do not over-fertilize with potassium and maintain adequate levels of both nitrogen and phosphorus., Control susceptible weeds such as black nightshade and hairy nightshade, and volunteer tomato plants throughout the rotation

Symptoms: Late blight of potato is identified by blackish/brown lesions on leaves and stems (Figures 3,4) that may be small at first and appear water-soaked or have chlorotic borders but expand rapidly and the entire leaf becomes become necrotic.
Severity of Diease: Very serious. disease spreads quickly in fields and can result in total crop failure if untreated.
Insectisides/Pesticides: Fungicides like Copper Based, Organocide Plant Doctor, SERENADE Garden, Monterey
Precautions: Rotations of two to three years to non-host crops are recommended to control late blight. Good drainage and good air movement will help reduce moisture levels in the crop canopy.  Only certified seed tubers should be planted.

Reason: Fungal, Powdery mildew spores typically drift into your garden with the wind, but if you’ve had powdery mildew occur in the past, new outbreaks may also come from dormant spores in old vegetative material or weeds nearby.
Symptoms:
Plants infected with powdery mildew look as if they have been dusted with flour.
Powdery mildew usually starts off as circular, powdery white spots, which can appear on leaves, stems, and sometimes fruit.
Powdery mildew usually covers the upper part of the leaves, but may grow on the undersides as well.
Young foliage is most susceptible to damage. Leaves turn yellow and dry out. The white spots of powdery mildew will spread to cover most of the leaves or affected areas.
Severity of Diease: Moderate. Affected plants can be removed & destroyed.
Natural Remedies:
spraying your plants with a bicarbonate solution:
Mix 1 teaspoon baking soda in 1 quart of water. Spray plants thoroughly, as the solution will only kill fungus that it comes into contact with.
Insectisides/Pesticides: Consider spraying infected plants with protectant (preventative) fungicides. Effective organic fungicides for treating powdery mildew include sulfur, lime-sulfur, neem oil, and potassium bicarbonate. These are most effective when used prior to infection or when you first see signs of the disease.
Precautions:
Choose plants for your garden that are resistant to powdery mildew. Many mildew-resistant varieties of cucurbits (melons, cucumbers, squash, etc.) have been developed and can be bought from major seed suppliers.
Plant in sunnier spots, as powdery mildew tends to develop more often in shady areas.
Selectively prune overcrowded areas to increase air circulation around your plants; this helps to reduce relative humidity.
Watering from overhead can help to wash spores off leaves.

Reason: Fungal, Disease emergence favored by wet foliage for extended periods of time.
Symptoms: Leaf scorch symptoms are very similar to the early stages of common (Mycosphaerella) leaf spot, with irregular dark purple spots being scattered over the upper leaf surface. Irregular dark purple or brown blotches on upper leaf surface which may colaesce to produce large purplish brown patches; tissue between blotches may turn purple or red; lesions may also develop on flowers and fruits; affected petals may wither and drop from plant; lesions may girdle peduncles causing death of fruit.
Severity of Diease: Less, This disease is very common and doesn't much affect the actual fruit.  In severe infestations, flowers and fruit may die.
Precautions: proper garden sanitation is key, removal of infected garden debris from the strawberry patch, as well as the frequent establishment of new strawberry transplants.

Reason: Fungal, Pathogenic for Tomato, The initial source of the disease is often infected seed, but it can be spread by a variety of factors, including rain, wind, on tools, on clothing, or via insect activity. High humidity and warm temperatures encourages the spread of the disease.
Symptoms: Symptoms mostly develop on leaves, appearing first on older leaves. Color of leaf mold spots on upper leaf surfaces progresses from pale green to yellow. Spots are not distinct as they lack a clearly defined border, in contrast with most other foliar diseases. Thus affected leaves may look like they have a general yellowing due to a nutrient deficiency.
Consequences: Foilage infection overall that causes them to wither and die. Ultimately, may affect yiled but no direct affect on fruit.
Natural Remedies: An apple-cider and vinegar mix is believed to treat the mold effectively. Corn and garlic spray can also be used to prevent fungi outbreaks before they even occur. There is also a milk-based spray that is touted as an all-natural, helpful cure for leaf mold.  let the plants air out and dry. If they are being cultivated in a greenhouse, expose them to dry air conditions, because the humidity that the fungus needs to survive and thrive is dried up in the open air
Insectisides/Pesticides: Active ingredients for Lead Mold Control fungicide: Difenoconazole and Cyprodinil, Difenoconazole and Mandipropamid,  Cymoxanil and Famoxadone, copper, mancozeb etc.
Precautions: try to keep the leaves dry when watering the plants, water in the early morning hours, that way the plant has plenty of time to dry before the sun comes out, which will keep the humidity around the leaves low.

Reason: Fungal, The fungus is spread by wind and rain, and flourishes in temperatures of 60 to 80 F. (16-27 C.)
Symptoms: Septoria leaf spot usually appears on the lower leaves after the first fruit sets. Spots are circular, about 1/16 to 1/4 inch in diameter with dark brown margins and tan to gray centers with small black fruiting structures. Characteristically, there are many spots per leaf. This disease spreads upwards from oldest to youngest growth. If leaf lesions are numerous, the leaves turn slightly yellow, then brown, and then wither. Fruit infection is rare.
Consequences: Affects foilage mostly and not the fruit.
Severity of Diease: Low as generally only leave is impacted and fruit is intact.
Insectisides/Pesticides: oranic-copper fungicide, biological - Bacillus Subtilis, chemical - Chlorothalonil-based like mancozeb
Precautions: remove all fallen plant debris, Keep weeds in check, Water the soil, not the plants, rotate crops, proper airflow

Reason: Transfers through spider mite organism which are not insects but of spider class.
Symptoms: Plant turning out yellow in patches and super-fine webs all over the plant, underside of leaves appear dusty
Consequences: Rapid webbing may occur in foilage and other parts as they are fast breeders.
Severity of Diease: Low. No direct effect on fruit.
Natural Remedies: Use of neem oil as miticides
Insectisides/Pesticides: Miticides suffice to control this like Mite-X, SNS-217,  Abamectin, Bifenazate, Spiromesifen
Precautions: Keep plant healthy, remove the affected plant,

Symptoms: The fungus infects all parts of plant. Infected leaves shows small, pinpoint, water soaked spots initially. As the disease progress the spots enlarge to become necrotic lesions with conspicuous concentric circles, dark margins and light brown centers. Whereas the fruits exhibit brown, slightly sunken flecks in the beginning but later the lesions become large pitted appearance.
Consequences: The fungus causes plants to lose their leaves; it is a major disease. If infection occurs before the fruit has developed, yields are low.
Insectisides/Pesticides: Fungicides like chlorothalonil, copper oxychloride or mancozeb.
Precautions: Remove the plant debris and burn them. Avoid over application of nitrogen fertilizer. If the disease is severe spray suitable fungicides.

Symptoms: Leaves of infected plants are small and curl upward; and show strong crumpling and interveinal and marginal yellowing. The internodes of infected plants become shortened and, together with the stunted growth, plants often take on a bushy appearance, which is sometimes referred to as 'bonsai' or broccoli'-like growth. Flowers formed on infected plants commonly do not develop and fall off (abscise). Fruit production is dramatically reduced, particularly when plants are infected at an early age, and it is not uncommon for losses of 100% to be experienced in fields with heavily infected plants.
Consequences: Can completely damage the fruit and affect overall yield very much
Natural Remedies: symptomatic plants should be carefully covered by a clear or black plastic bag and tied at the stem at soil line. Cut off the plant below the bag and allow bag with plant and whiteflies to desiccate to death on the soil surface for 1-2 days prior to placing the plant in the trash.
Insectisides/Pesticides: spray with azadirachtin (Neem), pyrethrin or insecticidal soap.
Precautions:
Remove and destroy old crop residue and volunteers on a regional basis.Select TYLCV-resistant varieties.Plant immediately after any tomato-free period or true winter season.
Avoid planting new fields near older fields (especially those with TYLCV-infected plants).
Manage WHITEFLIES.

Fruit/Crop/Plant: oses, beans, tobacco, tomatoes, potatoes, cucumbers and peppers
Reason: Viral Disease, Seed can be infected and pass the virus to the plant but the disease is usually introduced and spread primarily through human activity.
Symptoms: The disease is characterized by leaves that are mottled with yellow, white, and light or dark green spots and streaks (in other words, a “mosaic” of these colors).
Consequences: Loss of yield, affect soild, seeds and fruit
Severity of Diease: Very serious as no fungicides or chemical fertilizers work for this.
Insectisides/Pesticides: No insecticides and pesticides help to get rid off of this once plants are completely affected.
Precautions:
Fungicides will NOT treat this viral disease.
Plant resistant varieties when available or purchase transplants from a reputable source.
Do NOT save seed from infected crops.
Spot treat with least-toxic, natural pest control products, such as Safer Soap, Bon-Neem and diatomaceous earth, to reduce the number of disease carrying insects.
Harvest-Guard® row cover will help keep insect pests off vulnerable crops/ transplants and should be installed until bloom.
